questions.text: A patient presents with pain at the back of the neck. His x-ray is given below. Identify the fracture.
questions.solution:
The x-ray and the clinical features identify the fracture as clay-shoveller's fracture.

Clay-shoveller’s fracture refers to the avulsion fracture of the C7 spinous process.

It occurs due to the powerful contraction of the back muscles inserted into the spinous process. The injury is painful but harmless. No treatment is usually required. Neck exercises are encouraged.

The x-ray below shows a clay-shoveller's fracture.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the vertebra

Burst fracture - Vertical compression injury

Chance fracture - horizontal fracture of the vertebral body

Clay-shoveller's fracture - spinous process fracture of C6, C7 or T1

Dens fracture - Odontoid process fracture

Hangman's fracture - fracture of both pedicles of C2

Holdsworth fracture - unstable spinal fracture-dislocation at the thoracolumbar junction

Jefferson's fracture - fracture of first cervical vertebra

Motorcyclist's fracture - transverse fracture across base of the skull

Whiplash's injury - hyperextension followed by flexion 

Undertaker's fracture -Post-mortem fracture of the lower cervical spine with C6-C7 disc disruption

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presented to the emergency department with left wrist pain following a fall. On examination, the patient was found to have swelling and tenderness at his left thumb base. His x-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the above image are suggestive of Bennett fracture.

Bennett fracture is an intraarticular fracture that separates the palmar ulnar aspect of the base of the first metacarpal from the rest of the first metacarpal. It is the most common fracture involving the base of the thumb. 

The fracture is oblique and extends into the carpometacarpal joint. The strong pull of the abductor pollicis longus tendon that remains attached to the shaft of the metacarpal makes the fracture very unstable. X-ray shows a small triangle fragment remained in contact with the medial edge of the trapezium.

Plaster is applied with a felt pad over the fracture, and the first metacarpal is held in abduction and extension by flexing the MCP joint. Surgical fixation is done by passing a K-wire across the metacarpal base unto the carpus. 

Other options:

Option B: Rolando fracture is an intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration. The fracture can be managed with closed reduction and k wiring or by open reduction and plate fixation.

While both Bennett and Rolando fractures are intra-articular fractures of the metacarpal base, the differentiating feature is that Rolando fracture is a comminuted fracture producing 3 parts, whereas Bennett fracture is a 2 piece fracture.

The X-ray shown below depicts a Rolando fracture.

 

Option C: Boxer fracture is a fracture of the neck of the fifth metacarpal, as shown below.

 

Option D: Barton fracture is a split of the volar edge of the distal radius, as shown below.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.  

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: A 26-year-old athlete came to the orthopedic department with acute onset of pain in the lateral part of the foot while his routine practice. His radiograph of the foot is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above radiograph shows a transverse fracture on the base of the 5th metatarsal at the metaphyseal- diaphyseal junction and the most likely diagnosis is Jones fracture. 

A strong abduction force to the forefoot causes a bending moment in the metaphyseal-diaphyseal junction and results in Jones fracture. This type of injury occurs in a sudden change in direction by an athlete.

Patients with Jones fracture usually present with pain, swelling, and tenderness at the outer border of the foot following routine practice or an injury to the foot. Below knee walking plaster cast is applied for 3 weeks.

The image below shows an extra-articular fracture at the base of the 5th metatarsal.

Other options:

Option A- March fracture is a fracture of the 2nd metatarsal. It occurs due to repeated stress from prolonged walking or running. This may occur in new army recruits committed to marching. Hence the name march fracture. These lesions heal spontaneously.

The below radiograph shows a March fracture of the second metatarsal bone.

Option C- Lisfranc fracture is the fracture of metatarsal bases with associated tarsometatarsal dislocation. Lisfranc articulation comprises the tarsometatarsal joints. The tarsometatarsal joints comprise of first, second, and third metatarso-cuneiform joints along with the fourth and fifth metatarso-cuboid joints.

Option D- Aviator's fracture is a fracture of the neck of the talus due to forced dorsiflexion of the ankle.

The below radiograph shows an Aviator’s fracture. 

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the lower limb

Fracture Location
Hoffa fracture Coronal fracture of femoral condyles
Bumper fracture Comminuted fracture of lateral condyle of tibia 
Pilon fracture Comminuted intra-articular fracture of the distal end of the tibia 
Tillaux fracture Avulsion fracture of the tibia by the anterior tibiofibular ligament
Runner's fracture Fracture of the distal shaft of fibula 
Pott’s fracture Bimalleolar ankle fracture
Cotton’s fracture Trimalleolar ankle fracture
Aviator's fracture Fracture of neck of talus
Chopart’s fracture Fracture between talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints 
Lisfranc’s fracture-dislocation Fracture of metatarsal bases with associated tarsometatarsal dislocation
March fracture Fracture of the neck of 2nd or 3rd metatarsal
Jone's fracture

Extra-articular fracture at the base of the 5th metatarsal
Dancer’s fracture Fracture of distal shaft of the fifth metatarsal

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presented to the emergency department with a history of fall on a flexed wrist with dorsiflexion and pronation of the forearm. On examination, there is tenderness and painful dorsiflexion of the wrist. His X-ray is shown below. Which of the following statements are false about this condition?

choices.text: Unstable fractures are fixed with percutaneous pins or small screws
Conservative management is done with short arm cast
They are best seen on lateral view

questions.solution:
The given clinical history along with the X-ray showing the dorsal segment of distal radius fracture extending into the intra-articular region is suggestive of dorsal Barton's fracture. Barton's fractures are invariably intra-articular fractures. 

Barton’s fracture is an intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. The dorsal or volar rim of the distal radius can be involved and they are named accordingly.

Dorsal Barton:

It involves fracture-dislocation of the dorsal rim of the distal radius. It is caused due to falling on the flexed wrist with dorsiflexion and pronation of the distal forearm. These fractures are best seen on the lateral view and the radiograph shows proximal and posterior displacement of the dorsal lip of the distal radial articular surface.

Treatment: Conservative management is by short arm cast with the wrist in the neutral position. Surgical management is by open reduction and internal fixation with percutaneous pins or small plates and screws.

Volar Barton/Palmar rim dislocation:

It involves fracture-dislocation of the anterior/palmar rim of the distal radius. It is caused by palmar tensile stress and dorsal shear stress and may be associated with radial styloid fractures. The radiograph shows dorsal displacement of the palmar rim of the distal radial articular surface.

Treatment: Conservative management - long-arm cast. Even though reduction is simple, retention is usually difficult. Surgical fixation with K- wires, external fixators, and buttress plates are considered if the reduction is not properly retained. Ellis-T-shaped buttress plate fixation is mostly preferred.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: A post-menopausal woman presents with pain in the forearm after falling downstairs with hands outstretched. X-ray shows findings as seen in the image. Which of the following represents the position in which this patient's hand will be cast?

choices.text: Dorsal flexion, supination and radial deviation
Palmar flexion, pronation, and ulnar deviation.
Palmar flexion, pronation, and radial deviation.
Dorsal flexion, pronation and ulnar deviation

questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows an extra-articular transverse fracture of the radius just above the wrist with the distal fracture fragment is dorsally angulated is characteristic of Colles' fracture. The Colle's cast may be used for the management of this condition and here that hand is cast with the hand in palmar flexion, pronation, and ulnar deviation. 

Colle's fracture -

It is common in postmenopausal after a fall on an outstretched hand.

Clinical presentation -
The patient presents with pain, swelling, and deformity of the wrist. Tenderness may be present. The 'dinner fork deformity ' is the prominence on the back of the wrist and depression in the front. It is due to the dorsal angulation of the distal fracture fragment. The radial styloid process comes to lie at the same level or a little higher than the ulnar styloid process.  

Diagnosis -
Diagnosis is by X-ray.  X-rays show there is a transverse fracture of the radius at the cortico-cancellous junction. A dorsal tilt is the most common

Management -

  • Undisplaced fracture - immobilization in a below-elbow plaster cast for six weeks
  • Displaced fractures - manipulative reduction followed by immobilization in Colles' cast in palmar flexion, pronation, and ulnar deviation.
  • Comminuted fractures -  transfixed percutaneously using two K-wires

Related Pearl: Plaster casts and their uses:

  Name of cast   Usage

Minerva cast

 Cervical and upper thoracic spine disease

Risser’s cast

 Scoliosis 

Turn-buckle cast

 Scoliosis 

Shoulder spica

 Shoulder immobilization 

U-slab/hanging cast

 Fracture of the humerus 

Hip spica

 Fracture of the femur

Patellar tendon bearing cast

 Fracture of tibia

Colle’s cast (handshaking)

 Fracture lower end radius

Bachelor cast

 Developmental Dysplasia of Hip

Glass holding cast

 Fracture scaphoid

Burkhalter cast

 Metacarpal or phalangeal fractures

James slab

 Metacarpal and phalangeal fracture

questions.text: The fracture seen in the image given below is known as:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a fracture at the neck of 5th metacarpal which is known as Boxer's fracture.

Other options:

Option A: Bennett’s fracture-dislocation occurs at the base of the first metacarpal bone and is commonly due to punching.

Option B: Rolando fracture - intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

Option C: Chauffeur fracture - fracture of the radial styloid process.

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presented to the emergency department after a fall with complaints of left wrist pain. On physical examination, the patient was found to have swelling and tenderness at his left thumb base. He denied any paresthesias, tingling, or numbness. His X-Ray is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Rolando's fracture. It is an intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration with 3 major segments—the metacarpal shaft, the volar fragment, and the dorsal fragment.

Mechanism of injury of the Rolando fracture is an axial load crushing the articular surface. The patient often presents with a swollen and tender thumb base.

The fracture can be managed with closed reduction and k wiring or by open reduction and plate fixation.

Other options-

Bennet’s fracture is defined as an intra-articular two-part fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone which may occur due to forced abduction of the first metacarpal.

While both Bennett’s and Rolando's fractures are intra-articular fractures of the metacarpal base, the differentiating feature is that Rolando’s fracture is a comminuted fracture whereas Bennett’s fracture has a single fracture line.

Barton’s fracture is an intra-articular fracture of the distal radius.

Boxer’s fracture is a fracture of the neck of the fifth metacarpal.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.  

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department after he fell on his outstretched hand. An X-ray was performed and is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The provided history of falling on an outstretched arm and the X-ray revealing an oblique fracture in the lower third of the radius with dislocation of the distal radio-ulnar joint point to the diagnosis of Galeazzi's fracture.

Galeazzi's fracture is the fracture of the lower third of the radius and the subluxation or dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint. This injury usually happens when one falls on an outstretched hand. 

Patients present with pain, swelling, and deformity at the lower end of the radius. On examination, the disruption of the radio-ulnar joint can be elicited by pressing the lower end of the ulna. The ulna moves down and comes back like the key of a piano (piano-key sign). 

The aim of treatment for this fracture is to preserve supination and pronation of the forearm. In children, closed reduction is usually enough to achieve perfect reduction. However, in adults, open reduction using a k-wire fixation or compression plating is usually required. It is also important to look for ulnar nerve damage.

Galeazzi's fracture can cause complications such as malunion due to displacement of the fragment. This often results in deformity and limitation in supination and pronation.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: The X-ray image given below shows which type of Salter-Harris fracture?
questions.solution:
The above X-ray shows a fracture of the medial malleolus, with the fracture line in the epiphysis, below the physis. So it is a type III Salter-Harris fracture.

Salter-Harris classification is used to classify the injuries of the physis based on the radiological appearances. 

In a type III Salter-Harris fracture, the fracture splits the epiphysis and divides transversely to the other side through the hypertrophic layer of the physis. This damages the growth plate and results in growth disturbance. This type of fracture needs an accurate reduction to restore the joint surface.

Related Pearl: Types of Salter–Harris fractures- Mnemonic

There are nine types of Salter-Harris fractures. Among these, types I to V are more common.

The mnemonic "SALTER" can be used to help remember the first five types.

TYPE  MNEMONIC DESCRIPTION
Type I S = Slip/straight across Transverse fracture through the growth plate
Type II A = Away The fracture lies away from the joint. A fracture through the growth plate and the metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis
Type III L = Lower The fracture is below the physis in the epiphysis.
Type IV TE = Through Everything  A fracture through all three elements of the bone, the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis
Type V R = Rammed (crushed)  A compression fracture of the growth plate

Rarer types VI to IX have been added subsequently.

  • Type VI - Injury to the perichondral structures
  • Type VII - Isolated injury to the epiphyseal plate
  • Type VIII - Isolated injury to the metaphysis, with a potential injury related to endochondral ossification
  • Type IX - Injury to the periosteum that may interfere with membranous growth

questions.text: A 24-year old male patient  presented with a painful and swollen right thumb following a fall on an outstretched hand with his thumb extended. The X-ray image of his right thumb is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows the avulsion fracture of the ulnar base of the proximal phalanx of the thumb, known as Gamekeeper’s fracture.

A gamekeeper thumb, also known as skier’s thumb is an injury to the ulnar collateral ligament (UCL) of the first metacarpophalangeal joint. The UCL may get ruptured or avulsed from its site of insertion on the base of the proximal phalanx. Sometimes, a small fragment of the bone may be pulled off during the injury.

Injury is usually caused by a fall on an outstretched hand with radial and palmar abduction.

Patients present with pain, swelling, and ecchymosis around the first metacarpophalangeal joint.

Diagnosis can be made on plain radiographs and/or anteroposterior stress radiographs.

Other options:

Option a: Bennet fracture: It is an intra-articular, two-part fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone.

Option B: Rolando fracture is an intraarticular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone, with a ‘T’ or ‘Y’ configuration.

Option D: Epibasal fracture of thumb, also known as pseudo bennett’s fracture is a two-part fracture of the proximal first metacarpal bone.

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected. 

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: The garden-spade deformity is seen in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Garden spade deformity is seen in Smith's fracture. 

Smith’s fracture is the fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar displacement. It is also called reverse Colles' fracture because it has displacements opposite to that of Colles' fracture i.e, pronation, palmar angulation, and ulnar deviation.

The images given below shows Smith's fracture with garden-spade deformity.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: A radiograph of a patient with a history of injury to the hand is given below.  What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given radiograph showing a fracture of the radial styloid process points to a diagnosis of Chauffeur's fracture.

It is caused either by direct trauma to the wrist or traumatic radial deviation of the wrist.

Option A: Barton's fracture is an intra-articular fracture of the distal radius with volar subluxation of the wrist.

Option C: Smith's fracture is a distal radial fracture with associated volar angulation of the distal fracture fragment. It is also called reverse Colles fracture. 

Option D: Rolando’s fracture is an intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal.

questions.text: A baseball player presented with right upper arm pain. He started experiencing pain after he threw a ball and felt a pop. An upper arm X-ray was done and is given below. What is this fracture known as?
questions.solution:
The radiograph shows a displaced spiral fracture of the humerus at the junction of the middle-third and distal-third. This is known as Holstein-Lewis fracture.

There is a high risk of entrapment of the radial nerve in the bone fragments of this fracture. Hence this fracture is associated with radial nerve injury (wrist drop).

questions.text: The following X-Ray in a patient with a tear of the distal tibiofibular syndesmosis is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
The image shows a Maisonneuve Fracture.

Maissonneuve Fracture is a spiral fracture of proximal fibula and ankle ligament injury.

It usually occurs in cases of direct trauma or indirect twisting injury of the lower limb.

The fracture is often associated with other major injuries of lower limb.

questions.text: Identify the fracture.
questions.solution:
The image shows Pilon fracture, a distal tibia fracture.

The other name for Pilon fracture is Plafond fracture.

Mechanism of Injury: Axial Loading of the tibia.

Distal Tibia Fractures are more prone to go for nonunion because of relative avascularity.

The injury is better assessed with CT than with X Rays.

questions.text: Fracture shown in the radiograph is:
questions.solution:
The above radiograph shows Aviator’s fracture. 

An aviator fracture is a coronal-plane fracture of the neck of the talus resulting from forced dorsiflexion of ankle. 

It is the second most common talar fracture, after talar dome fractures. 

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the lower limb

Bumper fracture Comminuted fracture of lateral condyle of tibia 
Pilon fracture Comminuted intra-articular fracture of the distal end of the tibia 
Tillaux fracture Avulsion fracture of the tibia by the anterior tibiofibular ligament
Runner's fracture Fracture of the distal shaft of fibula 
Pott’s fracture Bimalleolar ankle fracture
Cotton’s fracture Trimalleolar ankle fracture
Aviator's fracture Fracture of neck of talus
Chopart’s fracture Fracture between talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints

Extra-articular fracture at the base of the 5th metatarsal

questions.text: The radiograph of a patient with a history of an injury to the foot is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given radiograph showing fracture and dislocation in the tarsometatarsal region points to a diagnosis of Lisfranc's fracture-dislocation.

The base of the second metatarsal base is dislocated from the middle cuneiform resulting in the widening of the first intermetatarsal space.

Chopart's fracture-dislocation is the dislocation of the midtarsal joint of the foot. It is associated with the fractures of the calcaneum, cuboid, and navicular bones. 

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the lower limb

Fracture Location
Hoffa fracture Coronal fracture of femoral condyles
Bumper fracture Comminuted fracture of lateral condyle of tibia 
Pilon fracture Comminuted intra-articular fracture of the distal end of the tibia 
Tillaux fracture Avulsion fracture of the tibia by the anterior tibiofibular ligament
Runner's fracture Fracture of the distal shaft of fibula 
Pott’s fracture Bimalleolar ankle fracture
Cotton’s fracture Trimalleolar ankle fracture
Aviator's fracture Fracture of neck of talus
Chopart’s fracture Fracture between talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints 
Lisfranc’s fracture-dislocation Fracture of metatarsal bases with associated tarsometatarsal dislocation
March fracture Fracture of the neck of 2nd or 3rd metatarsal
Jone's fracture

Extra-articular fracture at the base of the 5th metatarsal
Dancer’s fracture Fracture of distal shaft of the fifth metatarsal

questions.text: The fracture seen in the image given below is known as:
questions.solution:
The given image shows an extra-articular fracture at the base of 5th metatarsal which is known as Jones fracture.

questions.text: Fracture of the tibia caused by avulsion due to the anterior tibiofibular ligament is known as ____.
questions.solution:
The avulsion fracture of the tibia caused by the anterior tibiofibular ligament is known as the Tillaux fracture.

In children and adolescents, this fragment is usually the lateral part of the tibial epiphysis and would thus be considered as a Salter-Harris type 3 fracture. 

Pilon fracture refers to a comminuted intra-articular fracture of the distal tibia. These fractures are most often due to high-energy trauma such as a motor vehicle accident or a fall from a height. 

The below image shows Pilon fracture. 

An aviator's fracture is a coronal-plane fracture of the neck of the talus resulting from forced dorsiflexion of the ankle. It is the second most common talar fracture, after talar dome fractures.

Comminuted fracture of the lateral condyle of the tibia is known as a bumper fracture.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the lower limb

Fracture Location

questions.text: “Motorcyclist’s fracture” is which of the following

choices.text: Ring fracture of base of skull
Hinge fracture of base of skull

questions.solution:
Motorcyclist's fracture is Hinge fracture of the base of skull in which base of skull is divided into 2 halves, each moving independently of each other like a hinge.

Option b- ring fracture
Falls from a height onto the top of the skull or onto the feet, where the force is transmitted to the base of the skull through the spine, may result in ring fracture of the base of the skull around the foramen magnum

Option c- comminuted fracture
Comminuted fractures are those in which the bone shatters into multiple pieces.
They are commonly seen with the use of heavy weapon with broad striking surface and in vehicle and railway accidents.

Option d – depressed fracture
Depressed fractures will force fragments of skull inwards. Blows to the head by implements, like round-headed hammers, may cause depressed vault fractures.
